elements.content: The first double-walled bimetal–organic framework [Cd4K4(TADA)4(H2O)12]·6DMF (1, TADA = 3,3′-((6-hydroxy-1,3,5-triazine-2,4-diyl)­bis­(azanediyl)) dibenzoate) has been successfully constructed. In virtue of its high porosity and abundant basic sites, MOF 1 can be served as a high-efficiently size-selective heterogeneous catalyst for Knovenagel condensation reaction. Remarkably, 1 also exhibits excellent luminescent detectability for metronidazole (MDZ) with the highest quenching constant (K sv) of 1.16 × 105 M–1. The results demonstrate that 1 can be served as a unique bifunctional platform for antibiotics sensing and size-selective catalysis.
elements.clean_text: The first double-walled bimetal-organic framework [Cd4K4(TADA)4(H2O)12]⋅6DMF (1, TADA = 3,3'-((6-hydroxy-1,3,5-triazine-2,4-diyl)bis(azanediyl)) dibenzoate) has been successfully constructed. In virtue of its high porosity and abundant basic sites, MOF 1 can be served as a high-efficiently size-selective heterogeneous catalyst for Knovenagel condensation reaction. Remarkably, 1 also exhibits excellent luminescent detectability for metronidazole (MDZ) with the highest quenching constant (K sv) of 1.16 × 105 M-1. The results demonstrate that 1 can be served as a unique bifunctional platform for antibiotics sensing and size-selective catalysis.

elements.content: This work presents the first bimetallic double-walled metal−organic framework (MOF) based on octanuclear Cd­(II)−K­(I) clusters, which can be served as an efficiently bifunctional platform for antibiotics sensing and size-selective catalysis.
elements.clean_text: This work presents the first bimetallic double-walled metal-organic framework (MOF) based on octanuclear Cd(II)-K(I) clusters, which can be served as an efficiently bifunctional platform for antibiotics sensing and size-selective catalysis.

elements.content: As a family of promising porous crystalline materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have recently drawn special interest for their extensive applications in heterogeneous catalysis, guest storage and separation, chemical sensing, immobilized enzyme, optical devices, and so forth. Meanwhile, the designability of organic ligands and the variability of metal-involved secondary building units enforce the MOFs family unprecedented flourish. Hence, novel MOF materials have been always animatedly pursued, leading to extensive efforts by promoting the configurable complexity to achieve more captivating network architectures with outstanding properties. Thereinto, two methods have been applied to systematically increase the complexity of MOFs with certain functionality via double-walled or bimetallic constructions, which nevertheless have been less explored. In fact, most MOFs are constructed by single layer organic ligands and single metal centers or clusters, defined as monometallic single-walled MOFs. In contrast to these familiar MOF materials, there is an escalating interest in aspect of bimetallic or double-walled MOF systems with intriguing architectures and multifunctional features. Notably, the double-walled MOFs not only own more aesthetic qualities but also emerge as higher structural strengths to remarkably enhance the availability of MOFs in various areas due to the reinforced wall thickness.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As a family of promising porous crystalline materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have recently drawn special interest for their extensive applications in heterogeneous catalysis, guest storage and separation, chemical sensing, immobilized enzyme, optical devices, and so forth. Meanwhile, the designability of organic ligands and the variability of metal-involved secondary building units enforce the MOFs family unprecedented flourish. Hence, novel MOF materials have been always animatedly pursued, leading to extensive efforts by promoting the configurable complexity to achieve more captivating network architectures with outstanding properties. Thereinto, two methods have been applied to systematically increase the complexity of MOFs with certain functionality via double-walled or bimetallic constructions, which nevertheless have been less explored. In fact, most MOFs are constructed by single layer organic ligands and single metal centers or clusters, defined as monometallic single-walled MOFs. In contrast to these familiar MOF materials, there is an escalating interest in aspect of bimetallic or double-walled MOF systems with intriguing architectures and multifunctional features. Notably, the double-walled MOFs not only own more aesthetic qualities but also emerge as higher structural strengths to remarkably enhance the availability of MOFs in various areas due to the reinforced wall thickness.

elements.content: Conceptually, the double-walled MOFs can be generated by assembly of double-layered building blocks with metal centers or clusters as junctions. Nevertheless, the targeting design and synthesis of such MOFs requires a fundamental limitation, that is, both metal–cluster vertices and organic ligands must satisfy the demands of thickness, rigidity, size, and even shape of walls. Notably, the bimetallic vertex is more difficult to fabricate. Up to date, only a small numbers of MOFs with bimetallic or double-walled structures are known, whereas, to our knowledge, the bimetallic double-walled MOFs have not been documented. Actually, the construction of bimetallic double-walled MOFs is extremely desired, which can be considered as a new platform to explore the fascinating structures and potential applications.
elements.clean_text: Conceptually, the double-walled MOFs can be generated by assembly of double-layered building blocks with metal centers or clusters as junctions. Nevertheless, the targeting design and synthesis of such MOFs requires a fundamental limitation, that is, both metal-cluster vertices and organic ligands must satisfy the demands of thickness, rigidity, size, and even shape of walls. Notably, the bimetallic vertex is more difficult to fabricate. Up to date, only a small numbers of MOFs with bimetallic or double-walled structures are known, whereas, to our knowledge, the bimetallic double-walled MOFs have not been documented. Actually, the construction of bimetallic double-walled MOFs is extremely desired, which can be considered as a new platform to explore the fascinating structures and potential applications.

elements.content: In this work, a semirigid 3,3′-((6-hydroxy-1,3,5-triazine-2,4-diyl)­bis­(azanediyl)) dibenzoic acid (denoted as H3TADA) ligand with rich coordinated sites (−OH, −N, and −COOH) is selected, which can be assembled with K­(I) and Cd­(II) metals to successfully construct an unprecedented three-dimensional (3D) bimetallic double-walled MOF, namely [Cd4K4(TADA)4(H2O)12]·6DMF (1). Moreover, such a luminescent porous material can be applied in both antibiotics sensing and size-selective catalysis ().
elements.clean_text: In this work, a semirigid 3,3'-((6-hydroxy-1,3,5-triazine-2,4-diyl)bis(azanediyl)) dibenzoic acid (denoted as H3TADA) ligand with rich coordinated sites (-OH, -N, and -COOH) is selected, which can be assembled with K(I) and Cd(II) metals to successfully construct an unprecedented three-dimensional (3D) bimetallic double-walled MOF, namely [Cd4K4(TADA)4(H2O)12]⋅6DMF (1). Moreover, such a luminescent porous material can be applied in both antibiotics sensing and size-selective catalysis ().

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Illustration of a Double-Walled Bifunctional MOF for Luminescence Sensing and Heterogeneous Catalysis

elements.content: All chemicals of reagent grade were purchased and used without further purification. The ligand was prepared according to the reported approach. Elemental analysis of C, H and N was performed on a Leeman-Laboratories CE-440 analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were collected on a Shimadzu DTG-60A thermal analysis instrument from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating speed of 10 °C min–1 in air condition. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded in 4000–400 cm–1 on a Nicolet Avatar-370 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were taken on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer (40 kV and 40 mA) with Cu-K α radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at a sweep speed of 0.2° min–1 in the range of 4–40° (2θ). UV–vis absorption spectra were taken on a Shimadzu UV-2700 spectrophotometer. Luminescent spectra were carried out on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. Gas sorption experiment was performed on a surface area analyzer ASAP 2020. Gas chromatograph data were taken on an Agilent 7890A gas chromatograph machine.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals of reagent grade were purchased and used without further purification. The ligand was prepared according to the reported approach. Elemental analysis of C, H and N was performed on a Leeman-Laboratories CE-440 analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were collected on a Shimadzu DTG-60A thermal analysis instrument from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating speed of 10 °C min-1 in air condition. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded in 4000-400 cm-1 on a Nicolet Avatar-370 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were taken on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer (40 kV and 40 mA) with Cu-K α radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at a sweep speed of 0.2° min-1 in the range of 4-40° (2θ). UV-vis absorption spectra were taken on a Shimadzu UV-2700 spectrophotometer. Luminescent spectra were carried out on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. Gas sorption experiment was performed on a surface area analyzer ASAP 2020. Gas chromatograph data were taken on an Agilent 7890A gas chromatograph machine.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (20 mg, 0.065 mmol), KNO3 (10 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3TADA (26 mg, 0.07 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 4 mL), ethanol (1 mL), and HNO3 (2.5 M in DMF, 0.3 mL) was sealed into a 20 mL capped vessel. The vessel was heated at 75 °C for 1 week. Well-shaped crystals were obtained and washed with fresh DMF. Yield: 61% (based on Cd­(II) salt). FT-IR (cm–1): 3284 (br), 2924 (s), 1649 (s), 1616 (s), 1543 (s), 1506 (s), 1475 (s), 1437 (s), 1383 (s), 1290 (s), 1236 (s), 1098 (s), 905 (s), 838 (s), 806 (s), 766 (s), 682 (s), 668 (s), 620 (s), 554 (s). Anal. Calcd for C86H106‑O38N26K4Cd4: C 37.98, H 3.99, N 13.40%. Found: C 38.21, H 4.10, N 13.29%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cd4K4(TADA)4(H2O)12]⋅6DMF (1)

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (20 mg, 0.065 mmol), KNO3 (10 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3TADA (26 mg, 0.07 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 4 mL), ethanol (1 mL), and HNO3 (2.5 M in DMF, 0.3 mL) was sealed into a 20 mL capped vessel. The vessel was heated at 75 °C for 1 week. Well-shaped crystals were obtained and washed with fresh DMF. Yield: 61% (based on Cd(II) salt). FT-IR (cm-1): 3284 (br), 2924 (s), 1649 (s), 1616 (s), 1543 (s), 1506 (s), 1475 (s), 1437 (s), 1383 (s), 1290 (s), 1236 (s), 1098 (s), 905 (s), 838 (s), 806 (s), 766 (s), 682 (s), 668 (s), 620 (s), 554 (s). Anal. Calcd for C86H106-O38N26K4Cd4: C 37.98, H 3.99, N 13.40%. Found: C 38.21, H 4.10, N 13.29%.

elements.content: The powder of 1 (0.3 mg) was dispersed in DMF solution (3 mL) of antibiotics (1.0 × 10–4 mol L–1), including thiamphenicol (THI), penicillin (PCL), azithromycin (AZM), florfenicol (FFC), chloramphenicol (CAP), cycloheximide (CHX), furazolidone (FZD), sulfamethazine (SMZ), and metronidazole (MDZ), or anions (1.0 × 10–3 mol L–1, KX, X = Cl–, Br–, I–, NO3 –, PO4 3–, BrO3 –, MnO4 – and Cr2O7 2–), or nitroaromatic compounds (1.0 × 10–3 mol L–1), including nitrobenzene (NB), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 4-nitrotoluene (4-NT), p-nitrobenzoic acid (p-NBA), 1,4-dinitrobenzene (1,4-DNB), picric acid (PA), and 4-nitrophenol (4-NP). The luminescent data of the corresponding mixture were collected after 2 min. In addition, each measurement was repeated three times.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing Experiments

The powder of 1 (0.3 mg) was dispersed in DMF solution (3 mL) of antibiotics (1.0 × 10-4 mol L-1), including thiamphenicol (THI), penicillin (PCL), azithromycin (AZM), florfenicol (FFC), chloramphenicol (CAP), cycloheximide (CHX), furazolidone (FZD), sulfamethazine (SMZ), and metronidazole (MDZ), or anions (1.0 × 10-3 mol L-1, KX, X = Cl-, Br-, I-, NO3 -, PO4 3-, BrO3 -, MnO4 - and Cr2O7 2-), or nitroaromatic compounds (1.0 × 10-3 mol L-1), including nitrobenzene (NB), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 4-nitrotoluene (4-NT), p-nitrobenzoic acid (p-NBA), 1,4-dinitrobenzene (1,4-DNB), picric acid (PA), and 4-nitrophenol (4-NP). The luminescent data of the corresponding mixture were collected after 2 min. In addition, each measurement was repeated three times.

elements.content: The reproducibility of 1 toward sensing MDZ was studied in DMF solution. After the first quenching experiment, powder sample of 1 was recovered by centrifugation and washed with fresh DMF. The recovered solid was collected and then used in the successive quenching experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Recyclable Luminescence Experiments

The reproducibility of 1 toward sensing MDZ was studied in DMF solution. After the first quenching experiment, powder sample of 1 was recovered by centrifugation and washed with fresh DMF. The recovered solid was collected and then used in the successive quenching experiments.

elements.content: The as-synthesized microcrystalline solid of 1 was immersed in toluene for 2 h and dried in air before the catalytic reaction. In a typical case, substrate with aldehyde group (1.0 mmol), the other substrate (1.1 mmol), and catalyst 1 (50 mg) were put into a 25 mL glass reactor containing toluene (5 mL). The above mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 3 h. The yields were determined by GC with diphenyl as an internal standard. The reproducibility of 1 after catalytic reactions was recovered by centrifugation and washed with fresh toluene. The recovered solid was subsequently used in the successive catalytic experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Reactions

The as-synthesized microcrystalline solid of 1 was immersed in toluene for 2 h and dried in air before the catalytic reaction. In a typical case, substrate with aldehyde group (1.0 mmol), the other substrate (1.1 mmol), and catalyst 1 (50 mg) were put into a 25 mL glass reactor containing toluene (5 mL). The above mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 3 h. The yields were determined by GC with diphenyl as an internal standard. The reproducibility of 1 after catalytic reactions was recovered by centrifugation and washed with fresh toluene. The recovered solid was subsequently used in the successive catalytic experiments.

elements.content: The single crystal data of 1 were obtained on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Corrections for incident and diffracted beam absorption effects were applied using SADBAS. The structure was determined by direct methods and refined by the full matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXTL. All non-H atoms were located successfully from Fourier maps and refined by anisotropic thermal parameters. For the highly disordered nature of solvent molecules, they could not be finely made out in the refinement, and therefore the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was used to remove their diffraction contributions. The guest molecules can be calculated from the results of TGA and elemental analyses.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Crystallography

The single crystal data of 1 were obtained on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Corrections for incident and diffracted beam absorption effects were applied using SADBAS. The structure was determined by direct methods and refined by the full matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXTL. All non-H atoms were located successfully from Fourier maps and refined by anisotropic thermal parameters. For the highly disordered nature of solvent molecules, they could not be finely made out in the refinement, and therefore the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was used to remove their diffraction contributions. The guest molecules can be calculated from the results of TGA and elemental analyses.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction indicates that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P-1 space group with a 3D porous framework. The asymmetric unit contains four Cd2+ centers, four K+ ions, four deprotonated TADA3– ligands, and 12 terminal H2O molecules (Figure S1). As shown in a, the K+ ion is coordinated by six oxygen donors from two monodentate carboxylates, one hydroxyl group, and three terminal H2O (K–O = 2.163–2.647 Å). Simultaneously, the Cd2+ ion is linked by four oxygen atoms from two chelating carboxylates (Cd–O = 2.416–2.447 Å), and two nitrogen donors from two 1,3,5-triazine groups (Cd–N = 2.233–2.242 Å), respectively. In addition, four Cd2+ and four K+ ions are further connected by TADA3– ligands to construct a unique octanuclear heterometallic Cd­(II)–K­(I) clusters, which is first reported in MOF materials. As shown in b, each TADA3– ligand only has one coordination fashion in this structure, connecting to four Cd2+ and three K+ centers. Interestingly, the heterometallic Cd­(II)–K­(I) cluster is encapsulated by six pairs of TADA3– ligands to fabricate a dual-walled structure (c). The resultant dual-walled framework exhibits porous channels with an internal diameter of ca. 12 Å. After elimination of all guest molecules, the free volume of 1 is calculated to be 47.5% of the crystal volume (3562.1 Å3 of the 7495.0 Å3 unit cell volume) using PLATON/VOID analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description

Single crystal X-ray diffraction indicates that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P-1 space group with a 3D porous framework. The asymmetric unit contains four Cd2+ centers, four K+ ions, four deprotonated TADA3- ligands, and 12 terminal H2O molecules (Figure S1). As shown in a, the K+ ion is coordinated by six oxygen donors from two monodentate carboxylates, one hydroxyl group, and three terminal H2O (K-O = 2.163-2.647 Å). Simultaneously, the Cd2+ ion is linked by four oxygen atoms from two chelating carboxylates (Cd-O = 2.416-2.447 Å), and two nitrogen donors from two 1,3,5-triazine groups (Cd-N = 2.233-2.242 Å), respectively. In addition, four Cd2+ and four K+ ions are further connected by TADA3- ligands to construct a unique octanuclear heterometallic Cd(II)-K(I) clusters, which is first reported in MOF materials. As shown in b, each TADA3- ligand only has one coordination fashion in this structure, connecting to four Cd2+ and three K+ centers. Interestingly, the heterometallic Cd(II)-K(I) cluster is encapsulated by six pairs of TADA3- ligands to fabricate a dual-walled structure (c). The resultant dual-walled framework exhibits porous channels with an internal diameter of ca. 12 Å. After elimination of all guest molecules, the free volume of 1 is calculated to be 47.5% of the crystal volume (3562.1 Å3 of the 7495.0 Å3 unit cell volume) using PLATON/VOID analysis.

elements.content: Views of MOF 1. (a) The inorganic cluster; (b) the coordination mode of ligand; (c) the double-walled structure; and (d) the space filling pattern of the 3D framework (Cd, green; K, purple; C, gray; O, red; N, blue). The H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Views of MOF 1. (a) The inorganic cluster; (b) the coordination mode of ligand; (c) the double-walled structure; and (d) the space filling pattern of the 3D framework (Cd, green; K, purple; C, gray; O, red; N, blue). The H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) result of the as-synthesized MOF 1 exhibits a good agreement with the simulated pattern from the corresponding single crystal data, which confirms the phase purity of bulk sample (Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1 (Figure S3) show a slow weight loss of 23.89% before 200 °C, corresponding to the exclusion of guest molecules (calculated 24.07%). After that, the host framework starts to collapse and decompose with the increase of temperature. The as-synthesized sample was soaked in dry CH2Cl2 for about 2 days and then activated to obtain the evacuated sample. As illustrated in Figure S2, the PXRD pattern of activated sample indicates that the original skeleton could be well retained after removal of guest molecules. It is found that the corresponding characteristic peak of CO bond from DMF molecules at 1694 cm–1 disappears in the activated sample, indicating a complete elimination (Figure S4). In addition, the TGA curve of the evacuated sample further indicates that the solvent molecules are fully removed after activation (Figure S3). The permanent porosity of 1 can be confirmed by the N2 gas sorption at 77 K. As depicted in , the N2 sorption isotherm of the activated sample at 77 K exhibits a completely reversible type-I isotherm characteristic, indicating the presence of a microporous structure. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas are estimated to be 927.9 and 1047.2 m2 g–1 (at the low-pressure region P/P 0 < 0.10), respectively. To gain the in-depth insight into the pore structure, the porosity distribution is calculated to be ca. 11.8 Å by the density functional theory (DFT) method, being consistent with the single crystal data. Moreover, the corresponding total pore volume is 0.342 cm3 g–1.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD, Thermal Analysis, and Gas Sorption

The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) result of the as-synthesized MOF 1 exhibits a good agreement with the simulated pattern from the corresponding single crystal data, which confirms the phase purity of bulk sample (Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1 (Figure S3) show a slow weight loss of 23.89% before 200 °C, corresponding to the exclusion of guest molecules (calculated 24.07%). After that, the host framework starts to collapse and decompose with the increase of temperature. The as-synthesized sample was soaked in dry CH2Cl2 for about 2 days and then activated to obtain the evacuated sample. As illustrated in Figure S2, the PXRD pattern of activated sample indicates that the original skeleton could be well retained after removal of guest molecules. It is found that the corresponding characteristic peak of CO bond from DMF molecules at 1694 cm-1 disappears in the activated sample, indicating a complete elimination (Figure S4). In addition, the TGA curve of the evacuated sample further indicates that the solvent molecules are fully removed after activation (Figure S3). The permanent porosity of 1 can be confirmed by the N2 gas sorption at 77 K. As depicted in , the N2 sorption isotherm of the activated sample at 77 K exhibits a completely reversible type-I isotherm characteristic, indicating the presence of a microporous structure. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas are estimated to be 927.9 and 1047.2 m2 g-1 (at the low-pressure region P/P 0 < 0.10), respectively. To gain the in-depth insight into the pore structure, the porosity distribution is calculated to be ca. 11.8 Å by the density functional theory (DFT) method, being consistent with the single crystal data. Moreover, the corresponding total pore volume is 0.342 cm3 g-1.

elements.content: N2 sorption isotherm for activated sample 1 at 77 K (solid symbols, adsorption, and open symbols, desorption). Inset: the pore size distribution calculated by the DFT method.
elements.clean_text: 2  N2 sorption isotherm for activated sample 1 at 77 K (solid symbols, adsorption, and open symbols, desorption). Inset: the pore size distribution calculated by the DFT method.

elements.content: The luminescence properties of ground MOF 1 sample were explored in DMF at room temperature. It shows a broad emission at 367 nm under excitation at 317 nm (Figure S5). The maximum excitation and emission of the free H3TADA ligand are found at 341 and 404 nm, respectively (Figure S6), revealing a ligand-based luminescence for MOF 1. Significantly, the observed emission for 1 is significantly blue-shifted, which may be approximately ascribed to the coordination of TADA3– to K­(I) and Cd­(II) centers to reduce the skeleton vibrations. In addition, 1 shows a high luminesce intensity in DMF compared with those in other common organic solvents (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing

The luminescence properties of ground MOF 1 sample were explored in DMF at room temperature. It shows a broad emission at 367 nm under excitation at 317 nm (Figure S5). The maximum excitation and emission of the free H3TADA ligand are found at 341 and 404 nm, respectively (Figure S6), revealing a ligand-based luminescence for MOF 1. Significantly, the observed emission for 1 is significantly blue-shifted, which may be approximately ascribed to the coordination of TADA3- to K(I) and Cd(II) centers to reduce the skeleton vibrations. In addition, 1 shows a high luminesce intensity in DMF compared with those in other common organic solvents (Figure S7).

elements.content: To further explore the luminescence sensing ability of 1, the emission intensity of a ground sample was measured in different antibiotics (i.e., THI, PCL, AZM, FFC, CAP, CHX, FZD, SMZ, and MDZ) solutions (1.0 × 10–4 mol L–1) at room temperature after 2 min (a). The results reveal that the luminescent intensity of MOF 1 in MDZ solution presents a significant quenching phenomenon, although the other antibiotics also decrease at different levels. The order of quenching efficiency is MDZ > SMZ > FZD > FFC > CHX > CAP > AZM > PCL > THI. Once MDZ solution is added, the luminescent response rate for MOF 1 instantly decreases and reaches a minimum value after only 50 s, which can be further maintained for a long time (b). Also, the anti-interference tests were performed to explore the selectivity for MDZ (Figure S8). MOF 1 was soaked in the mixed antibiotics DMF solution without or with MDZ and the corresponding luminescence intensity significantly decreased after adding MDZ. It illustrates that the luminescence intensity is only in relation to MDZ and 1 can be implemented as a highly selective luminescent sensor for MDZ. To achieve more in-depth understanding of the luminescence quenching process, concentration-dependent experiments of MDZ were monitored at different concentrations. As shown in c, the luminescence intensity of MOF 1 gradually reduces with the increasing amount of MDZ. The detectability could be quantitatively determined by the quenching constant (K sv), calculating from the Stern–Volmer equation: (I 0/I) = K sv[M] + 1. Thereinto, I 0 and I express the luminescent intensities of 1 without and with MDZ, respectively, and [M] is the molar concentration of MDZ. The detail analysis illustrates that there is a fine linear relationship (with R 2 = 0.9949) between I 0/I – 1 and the MDZ concentration (c insert). The quenching efficiencies of 1 are 13%, 54%, and 100% in the presence of MDZ of 1.5 × 10–6, 1.1 × 10–5, and 1.2 × 10–4 mol L–1, respectively (Figure S9). Remarkably, the K sv value is about 1.16 × 105 M–1, which is most sensitive in all reported MOF-based sensors (Table S1).
elements.clean_text: To further explore the luminescence sensing ability of 1, the emission intensity of a ground sample was measured in different antibiotics (i.e., THI, PCL, AZM, FFC, CAP, CHX, FZD, SMZ, and MDZ) solutions (1.0 × 10-4 mol L-1) at room temperature after 2 min (a). The results reveal that the luminescent intensity of MOF 1 in MDZ solution presents a significant quenching phenomenon, although the other antibiotics also decrease at different levels. The order of quenching efficiency is MDZ > SMZ > FZD > FFC > CHX > CAP > AZM > PCL > THI. Once MDZ solution is added, the luminescent response rate for MOF 1 instantly decreases and reaches a minimum value after only 50 s, which can be further maintained for a long time (b). Also, the anti-interference tests were performed to explore the selectivity for MDZ (Figure S8). MOF 1 was soaked in the mixed antibiotics DMF solution without or with MDZ and the corresponding luminescence intensity significantly decreased after adding MDZ. It illustrates that the luminescence intensity is only in relation to MDZ and 1 can be implemented as a highly selective luminescent sensor for MDZ. To achieve more in-depth understanding of the luminescence quenching process, concentration-dependent experiments of MDZ were monitored at different concentrations. As shown in c, the luminescence intensity of MOF 1 gradually reduces with the increasing amount of MDZ. The detectability could be quantitatively determined by the quenching constant (K sv), calculating from the Stern-Volmer equation: (I 0/I) = K sv[M] + 1. Thereinto, I 0 and I express the luminescent intensities of 1 without and with MDZ, respectively, and [M] is the molar concentration of MDZ. The detail analysis illustrates that there is a fine linear relationship (with R 2 = 0.9949) between I 0/I - 1 and the MDZ concentration (c insert). The quenching efficiencies of 1 are 13%, 54%, and 100% in the presence of MDZ of 1.5 × 10-6, 1.1 × 10-5, and 1.2 × 10-4 mol L-1, respectively (Figure S9). Remarkably, the K sv value is about 1.16 × 105 M-1, which is most sensitive in all reported MOF-based sensors (Table S1).

elements.content: (a) Luminescent intensity of as-synthesized 1 in different antibiotics solutions about 2 min at room temperature; (b) luminescent response rates of 1 in MDZ solutions measured at different time intervals; (c) the emission spectra and K sv value of 1 titrated with MDZ; and (d) reproducibility of 1 dispersed in the MDZ solution (6.0 × 10–5 mol L–1).
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Luminescent intensity of as-synthesized 1 in different antibiotics solutions about 2 min at room temperature; (b) luminescent response rates of 1 in MDZ solutions measured at different time intervals; (c) the emission spectra and K sv value of 1 titrated with MDZ; and (d) reproducibility of 1 dispersed in the MDZ solution (6.0 × 10-5 mol L-1).

elements.content: The reusability plays a crucial role in the luminescent detection. MOF 1 can be easily recycled at least four times by centrifuged and further washed with fresh DMF, which ultimately maintain the luminescent intensity and detection performance (d). The PXRD patterns confirm the recycle samples can retain the 3D porous framework (Figure S10). According to the UV–vis absorption spectra of antibiotics, only MDZ shows the spectral overlap with the excitation spectrum of 1 (Figure S11). Thus, the underlying mechanism of luminescence intensity decreased by MDZ may be properly ascribed to a competitive adsorption of excitation wavelength energy between 1 and MDZ, which is similar to the reported MOFs. Further, anions and nitroaromatic compounds were selected to estimate the sensing ability of 1 through a similar test method for metal ions (Figures S12 and S13). It shows that 1 both possesses the luminescence sensing ability for Cr2O7 2– (K sv = 2.9 × 103 M–1, R2 = 0.9931) and 4-nitrophenol (K sv = 4.7 × 103 M–1, R2 = 0.9993) (Figures S14–S17), which could also be attributed to the similar reason likely MDZ, according to UV–vis absorption spectra of these analytes (Figures S18 and S19).
elements.clean_text: The reusability plays a crucial role in the luminescent detection. MOF 1 can be easily recycled at least four times by centrifuged and further washed with fresh DMF, which ultimately maintain the luminescent intensity and detection performance (d). The PXRD patterns confirm the recycle samples can retain the 3D porous framework (Figure S10). According to the UV-vis absorption spectra of antibiotics, only MDZ shows the spectral overlap with the excitation spectrum of 1 (Figure S11). Thus, the underlying mechanism of luminescence intensity decreased by MDZ may be properly ascribed to a competitive adsorption of excitation wavelength energy between 1 and MDZ, which is similar to the reported MOFs. Further, anions and nitroaromatic compounds were selected to estimate the sensing ability of 1 through a similar test method for metal ions (Figures S12 and S13). It shows that 1 both possesses the luminescence sensing ability for Cr2O7 2- (K sv = 2.9 × 103 M-1, R2 = 0.9931) and 4-nitrophenol (K sv = 4.7 × 103 M-1, R2 = 0.9993) (Figures S14-S17), which could also be attributed to the similar reason likely MDZ, according to UV-vis absorption spectra of these analytes (Figures S18 and S19).

elements.content: On the basis of the crystal structure, 1 has both high porosity and abundant Lewis basic sites to be considered as a size-selective heterogeneous catalyst for Knovenagel condensation reaction. The as-synthesized sample 1 was immersed in toluene for 2 h and further dried in air before the catalytic reactions. In a typical reaction condition, the substrate with aldehyde group (1 mmol), the other substrate (1.1 mmol), heterogeneous catalyst (1, 50 mg), and toluene (5 mL) were mixed in a bottle (25 mL) and stirred at 353 K for 3 h. The corresponding yields were calculated by GC with diphenyl as an internal standard. It contains all the catalytic results of different substrates in . As shown in entry 1, the yield of 2-benzylidenemalononitrile can accomplish approximately 100% after 3 h. Further, the substrates with different sizes were extended under the same catalytic reactions. The results also show outstanding yields (about 100%) in the presence of withdrawing groups (−F, −NO2, and −phenyl, entries 2, 3, and 4). Nevertheless, the yield of aldehyde with electron donating group (−CH3, entry 5) slightly decreases to 93%. With the increase of molecule size from malononitrile to ethyl cyanacetate and diethyl malonate, the yields decrease from 100% to 85% and 23%, respectively (entries 6 and 7). The results reveal that the reactant size will significantly affect the catalytic efficiency, which could be further confirmed by kinetic analysis (a). When MOF 1 was filtered from the reaction system at 30 min, the reaction would be interrupted and the yield would be almost unchanged, confirming the necessity of catalysis (a). Moreover, the catalytic reaction almost cannot proceed in the absence of 1 (a and entry 8).
elements.clean_text:
Catalysis Properties

On the basis of the crystal structure, 1 has both high porosity and abundant Lewis basic sites to be considered as a size-selective heterogeneous catalyst for Knovenagel condensation reaction. The as-synthesized sample 1 was immersed in toluene for 2 h and further dried in air before the catalytic reactions. In a typical reaction condition, the substrate with aldehyde group (1 mmol), the other substrate (1.1 mmol), heterogeneous catalyst (1, 50 mg), and toluene (5 mL) were mixed in a bottle (25 mL) and stirred at 353 K for 3 h. The corresponding yields were calculated by GC with diphenyl as an internal standard. It contains all the catalytic results of different substrates in . As shown in entry 1, the yield of 2-benzylidenemalononitrile can accomplish approximately 100% after 3 h. Further, the substrates with different sizes were extended under the same catalytic reactions. The results also show outstanding yields (about 100%) in the presence of withdrawing groups (-F, -NO2, and -phenyl, entries 2, 3, and 4). Nevertheless, the yield of aldehyde with electron donating group (-CH3, entry 5) slightly decreases to 93%. With the increase of molecule size from malononitrile to ethyl cyanacetate and diethyl malonate, the yields decrease from 100% to 85% and 23%, respectively (entries 6 and 7). The results reveal that the reactant size will significantly affect the catalytic efficiency, which could be further confirmed by kinetic analysis (a). When MOF 1 was filtered from the reaction system at 30 min, the reaction would be interrupted and the yield would be almost unchanged, confirming the necessity of catalysis (a). Moreover, the catalytic reaction almost cannot proceed in the absence of 1 (a and entry 8).

elements.content: (a) Kinetics analysis of Knovenagel condensation reaction; (b) the recyclability of 1 as a heterogeneous catalyst.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Kinetics analysis of Knovenagel condensation reaction; (b) the recyclability of 1 as a heterogeneous catalyst.

elements.content:
Knovenagel Condensation Reaction Catalysed by <bold>1</bold> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref> entry –R substrate yield (%) 1 –H A ∼100 2 –F A ∼100 3 –NO2 A ∼100 4 –phenyl A ∼100 5 –CH3 A 93 6 –H B 85 7 –H C 23 8 –H A trace 9 –H A ∼100

Reaction conditions: substrate with aldehyde group (1 mmol), the other substrate (1.1 mmol), tolune (5 mL), catalyst (50 mg), 353 K, and 3 h.

The same reaction conditions as in footnote a but without the catalyst.

The recyclability test after five times.

The yields were determined by GC with diphenyl as an internal standard.

In addition, it is a significant essential for the heterogeneous catalyst to separate and reuse. MOF 1 can be easily recollected by centrifuging at 7000 r min–1 for 1 min and then, washed with fresh toluene. As illustrated in entry 9 and b, the catalytic effect of the recycled sample was nearly no change after five recycles. The PXRD patterns further indicate that the initiating structure can be retained well after the reactions (Figure S20). All the results clearly reveal that 1 can be served as an excellent size-selective heterogeneous catalyst for the Knovenagel condensation reaction.
elements.clean_text: In addition, it is a significant essential for the heterogeneous catalyst to separate and reuse. MOF 1 can be easily recollected by centrifuging at 7000 r min-1 for 1 min and then, washed with fresh toluene. As illustrated in entry 9 and b, the catalytic effect of the recycled sample was nearly no change after five recycles. The PXRD patterns further indicate that the initiating structure can be retained well after the reactions (Figure S20). All the results clearly reveal that 1 can be served as an excellent size-selective heterogeneous catalyst for the Knovenagel condensation reaction.

elements.content: In summary, we have first designed and prepared a porous bimetallic double-walled MOF material based on unique Cd­(II)–K­(I) octanuclear clusters, which is further explored as a bifunctional platform for high-efficient sensing of antibiotics and size-selective heterogeneous catalyst for the Knovenagel condensation reaction. We anticipate that this work can offer a promising approach to achieve more fascinating MOF materials with unique framework architectures and superior performances in terms of targeting applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have first designed and prepared a porous bimetallic double-walled MOF material based on unique Cd(II)-K(I) octanuclear clusters, which is further explored as a bifunctional platform for high-efficient sensing of antibiotics and size-selective heterogeneous catalyst for the Knovenagel condensation reaction. We anticipate that this work can offer a promising approach to achieve more fascinating MOF materials with unique framework architectures and superior performances in terms of targeting applications.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (20 mg, 0.065 mmol), KNO3 (10 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3TADA (26 mg, 0.07 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 4 mL), ethanol (1 mL), and HNO3 (2.5 M in DMF, 0.3 mL) was sealed into a 20 mL capped vessel. The vessel was heated at 75 °C for 1 week. Well-shaped crystals were obtained and washed with fresh DMF. Yield: 61% (based on Cd­(II) salt). FT-IR (cm–1): 3284 (br), 2924 (s), 1649 (s), 1616 (s), 1543 (s), 1506 (s), 1475 (s), 1437 (s), 1383 (s), 1290 (s), 1236 (s), 1098 (s), 905 (s), 838 (s), 806 (s), 766 (s), 682 (s), 668 (s), 620 (s), 554 (s). Anal. Calcd for C86H106‑O38N26K4Cd4: C 37.98, H 3.99, N 13.40%. Found: C 38.21, H 4.10, N 13.29%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cd4K4(TADA)4(H2O)12]⋅6DMF (1)

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (20 mg, 0.065 mmol), KNO3 (10 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3TADA (26 mg, 0.07 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 4 mL), ethanol (1 mL), and HNO3 (2.5 M in DMF, 0.3 mL) was sealed into a 20 mL capped vessel. The vessel was heated at 75 °C for 1 week. Well-shaped crystals were obtained and washed with fresh DMF. Yield: 61% (based on Cd(II) salt). FT-IR (cm-1): 3284 (br), 2924 (s), 1649 (s), 1616 (s), 1543 (s), 1506 (s), 1475 (s), 1437 (s), 1383 (s), 1290 (s), 1236 (s), 1098 (s), 905 (s), 838 (s), 806 (s), 766 (s), 682 (s), 668 (s), 620 (s), 554 (s). Anal. Calcd for C86H106-O38N26K4Cd4: C 37.98, H 3.99, N 13.40%. Found: C 38.21, H 4.10, N 13.29%.

cln_elements.content:
The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) result of the as-synthesized MOF 1 exhibits a good agreement with the simulated pattern from the corresponding single crystal data, which confirms the phase purity of bulk sample (Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1 (Figure S3) show a slow weight loss of 23.89% before 200 °C, corresponding to the exclusion of guest molecules (calculated 24.07%). After that, the host framework starts to collapse and decompose with the increase of temperature. The as-synthesized sample was soaked in dry CH2Cl2 for about 2 days and then activated to obtain the evacuated sample. As illustrated in Figure S2, the PXRD pattern of activated sample indicates that the original skeleton could be well retained after removal of guest molecules. It is found that the corresponding characteristic peak of CO bond from DMF molecules at 1694 cm–1 disappears in the activated sample, indicating a complete elimination (Figure S4). In addition, the TGA curve of the evacuated sample further indicates that the solvent molecules are fully removed after activation (Figure S3). The permanent porosity of 1 can be confirmed by the N2 gas sorption at 77 K. As depicted in , the N2 sorption isotherm of the activated sample at 77 K exhibits a completely reversible type-I isotherm characteristic, indicating the presence of a microporous structure. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas are estimated to be 927.9 and 1047.2 m2 g–1 (at the low-pressure region P/P 0 < 0.10), respectively. To gain the in-depth insight into the pore structure, the porosity distribution is calculated to be ca. 11.8 Å by the density functional theory (DFT) method, being consistent with the single crystal data. Moreover, the corresponding total pore volume is 0.342 cm3 g–1.

Luminescence Sensing

The luminescence properties of ground MOF 1 sample were explored in DMF at room temperature. It shows a broad emission at 367 nm under excitation at 317 nm (Figure S5). The maximum excitation and emission of the free H3TADA ligand are found at 341 and 404 nm, respectively (Figure S6), revealing a ligand-based luminescence for MOF 1. Significantly, the observed emission for 1 is significantly blue-shifted, which may be approximately ascribed to the coordination of TADA3– to K­(I) and Cd­(II) centers to reduce the skeleton vibrations. In addition, 1 shows a high luminesce intensity in DMF compared with those in other common organic solvents (Figure S7).
cln_elements.clean_text:
PXRD, Thermal Analysis, and Gas Sorption

The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) result of the as-synthesized MOF 1 exhibits a good agreement with the simulated pattern from the corresponding single crystal data, which confirms the phase purity of bulk sample (Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1 (Figure S3) show a slow weight loss of 23.89% before 200 °C, corresponding to the exclusion of guest molecules (calculated 24.07%). After that, the host framework starts to collapse and decompose with the increase of temperature. The as-synthesized sample was soaked in dry CH2Cl2 for about 2 days and then activated to obtain the evacuated sample. As illustrated in Figure S2, the PXRD pattern of activated sample indicates that the original skeleton could be well retained after removal of guest molecules. It is found that the corresponding characteristic peak of CO bond from DMF molecules at 1694 cm-1 disappears in the activated sample, indicating a complete elimination (Figure S4). In addition, the TGA curve of the evacuated sample further indicates that the solvent molecules are fully removed after activation (Figure S3). The permanent porosity of 1 can be confirmed by the N2 gas sorption at 77 K. As depicted in , the N2 sorption isotherm of the activated sample at 77 K exhibits a completely reversible type-I isotherm characteristic, indicating the presence of a microporous structure. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas are estimated to be 927.9 and 1047.2 m2 g-1 (at the low-pressure region P/P 0 < 0.10), respectively. To gain the in-depth insight into the pore structure, the porosity distribution is calculated to be ca. 11.8 Å by the density functional theory (DFT) method, being consistent with the single crystal data. Moreover, the corresponding total pore volume is 0.342 cm3 g-1.

Luminescence Sensing

The luminescence properties of ground MOF 1 sample were explored in DMF at room temperature. It shows a broad emission at 367 nm under excitation at 317 nm (Figure S5). The maximum excitation and emission of the free H3TADA ligand are found at 341 and 404 nm, respectively (Figure S6), revealing a ligand-based luminescence for MOF 1. Significantly, the observed emission for 1 is significantly blue-shifted, which may be approximately ascribed to the coordination of TADA3- to K(I) and Cd(II) centers to reduce the skeleton vibrations. In addition, 1 shows a high luminesce intensity in DMF compared with those in other common organic solvents (Figure S7).

metadata.title:
A Double-Walled Bimetal–Organic Framework for
Antibiotics Sensing and Size-Selective Catalysis
